issues.text: Whether the allotment of separate rooms to different sections of the Bar in the Calcutta High Court offends Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A V. Viswanatha Sastri for the Petitioners wants to raise the larger question about the companystitutionality of the allotment of rooms to different sections of the Bar in the Calcutta High Court. We think that it is desirable that the petitioners should move the learned Chief Justice of the Calcutta High Court and place before him their case that the allotment of the rooms offends against Art. 14 of

issues.text: Whether the High Court orders providing separate accommodation to different associations of legal practitioners is based on reasonable classification without discrimination under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: the High Court orders regulating the manner in which the different associations shall be provided accommodation was based on reasonable classification of legal practitioners, and that there was nodiscrimination.

issues.text: Whether the classification of the Bar into three sections (pleaders only, pleaders and actors, actors only) for separate accommodation is reasonable and does not violate Article 14

anchor.surface_text: This classification in our opinion is reasonable taking into account the past history to which we have already referred. Grant of separate accommodation therefore to these three sections of the Bar cannot amount to denial of equality before the law.

issues.text: Whether a writ in the nature of mandamus lies against the respondents including the State, Chief Justice, and Bar Library Club members for directing equal use of accommodation without discrimination

anchor.surface_text: pray for a writ in the nature of mandamus directing them to allow the petitioners

issues.text: Whether the rules of the Original Side requiring chambers reading for Barristers and the provisions for separate accommodation are ultra vires the Indian Bar Councils Act and amount to discrimination

anchor.surface_text: The provisions made in the rules for original side of the said Court and for Barristers are ultra vires the Indian Bar Councils Act and Or amounts to discrimination. Thus, the gist of the petitioners companylaint is that they have been denied by the State equality before the law.

issues.text: Whether the writ petition is maintainable against the Bar Library Club as a private association and its members who are not public servants

anchor.surface_text: They state that they were number public servants, and, therefore, numberwrit-lay against them or against any other member of the Bar Library Club, or the Bar Library Club itself, for anything done by them. They denied the petitioners right to be members of the Club or to use the rooms in the possession. of the Club.

arguments.claim: Petitioners entitled to add 'Barrister-at-Law' and use Bar Library Club accommodation as they were called to English Bar.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners duly notified to the Registrar, Original Side of the Court, to correct the register of advocates practising on the Original side, by adding Barrister-at-Law after their names. Thus, the petitioners who started as advocates of the Court claim to have become entitled to the additional qualification of a Barrister though they had not read for a period of 12 months in the chambers of a practising Barrister in England or a practising Barrister in Calcutta, as required by the rules of the Original side of the Court.

arguments.claim: Three classes: plead-only (Barristers), plead/act (Advocates), act-only (Attorneys); separate accommodation justified historically.

anchor.surface_text: This classification in our opinion is reasonable taking into account the past history to which we have already referred. Grant of separate accommodation therefore to these three sections of the Bar cannot amount to denial of equality before the law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or of further improvements in the relations between the different sections of the Bar so that they may grow into a unified bar with all the best tradi

arguments.claim: Unified Bar desirable but requires mutual agreement; separate sections continue.

anchor.surface_text: Successive Chief Justices... sympathized with the attempt... but... only by mutual agreement amongst the two sections of Advocates.

holdings.text: This classification in our opinion is reasonable taking into account the past history to which we have already referred. Grant of separate accommodation therefore to these three sections of the Bar cannot amount to denial of equality before the law.

anchor.surface_text: This classification in our opinion is reasonable taking into account the past history to which we have already referred. Grant of separate accommodation therefore to these three sections of the Bar cannot amount to denial of equality before the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification into plead-only, plead-and-act, act-only based on historical functions and practice differences satisfies reasonable classification test under Art. 14.

holdings.text: The Bar Library Club has already agreed before us to change its rules so that the Club conforms exactly to the first section and admission to it will be governed by rules which are common to all lawyers who want only to plead there is therefore no reason to interfere with accommodation provided by the Court to the three sections of the Bar.

anchor.surface_text: The Bar Library Club has already agreed before us to change its rules so that the Club conforms exactly to the first section and admission to it will be governed by rules which are common to all lawyers who want only to plead there is therefore no reason to interfere with accommodation provided by the Court to the three sections of the Bar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Club's amendment opens membership to non-Barrister plead-only advocates without discrimination, aligning with first category; withdrawal of limiting rule 25 provision assures fair admission.

holdings.text: We have also no doubt that the Chief Justice will see that the undertaking given by the Bar Library Club will be carried out. We may add that in case the undertaking is not carried out, the Chief Justice will see that necessary and appropriate rules are framed which will carry out the purpose for which the accommodation is placed at the disposal of the three sections of the Bar and the same are implemented so that there is no denial of equality before the law.

anchor.surface_text: We have also no doubt that the Chief Justice will see that the undertaking given by the Bar Library Club will be carried out. We may add that in case the undertaking is not carried out, the Chief Justice will see that necessary and appropriate rules are framed which will carry out the purpose for which the accommodation is placed at the disposal of the three sections of the Bar and the same are implemented so that there is no denial of equality before the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chief Justice administratively responsible for ensuring no discrimination in accommodation use; to enforce undertaking or frame rules if needed.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter, the petition fails and is hereby dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the petition fails and is hereby dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No violation of Art. 14 or other fundamental right; no basis for mandamus as classification upheld and arrangements satisfactory.

holdings.text: This arrangement, agreed to by the respondents 3 and 4 representing their Club, is a great improvement upon the position as it was when this Court was moved, and we are satisfied that nothing better could have been achieved as a result of these proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: This arrangement, agreed to by the respondents 3 and 4 representing their Club, is a great improvement upon the position as it was when this Court was moved, and we are satisfied that nothing better could have been achieved as a result of these proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended club rules and undertaking resolve discrimination claims against private club aspects; writ proceedings achieve practical resolution.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the petition fails and is hereby dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed. No mandamus issued for access to Bar Library Club accommodation or to end discrimination among advocates. Classification of Bar into three sections (pleaders only, pleaders and actors, actors only) held reasonable, not violating Article 14.
directions: Bar Library Club to implement amended rules admitting non-Barrister advocates who practise only pleading, without limiting numbers (withdrawal of restrictive addition to Rule 25).
Chief Justice to ensure Bar Library Club's undertaking is carried out.
If undertaking not carried out, Chief Justice to frame and implement necessary rules ensuring accommodation for the three sections of the Bar without denial of equality.
